The **economy of Chad** suffers from the landlocked country's geographic
remoteness, drought, lack of infrastructure, and political turmoil. About 80%
of the population depends on subsistence agriculture, including livestock
herding. Of Africa's Francophone countries, Chad benefited least from the 50%
devaluation of their currencies in January 1994. Financial aid from the World
Bank, the African Development Bank, and other sources is directed mainly at
improving agriculture, especially livestock production. Because of a lack of
financing, the development of oil fields near Doba, originally due to finish
in 2000, was delayed until 2003. It was finally developed and is now operated
by ExxonMobil. until 2023 Regarding gross domestic product, Chad ranks 147th
globally with $11.051 billion as of 2018.
openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Chad is significantly impacted by its geographic remoteness due to being a landlocked country, which contributes to economic challenges.
• Chad's economy is also affected by recurrent droughts, inadequate infrastructure, and ongoing political turmoil.
• Approximately 80% of Chad's population relies on subsistence agriculture, including livestock herding, for their livelihood.
• Among Africa's Francophone countries, Chad benefited the least from the 50% devaluation of their currencies that occurred in January 1994.

• International financial aid from organizations such as the World Bank and the African Development Bank is primarily targeted at improving agricultural productivity, with a particular focus on livestock production.
• The development of oil fields near Doba was delayed due to a lack of financing; initially scheduled for completion in 2000, the project was postponed until 2003.
• The Doba oil fields were eventually developed and are operated by ExxonMobil, with operations continuing until at least 2023.
• As of 2018, Chad's gross domestic product (GDP) was valued at $11.051 billion, ranking it 147th globally.
• In 2023, Chad produced approximately 878,000 tons of sorghum, making it a significant staple crop for the country.
• The country’s groundnut production reached about 782,000 tons in 2023, contributing to both domestic consumption and export potential.
• Millet production in Chad was approximately 634,000 tons in 2023, serving as an essential food source for the population.
• Total cereal production in Chad was around 552,000 tons in 2023, encompassing various cereal grains vital for national food security.
• Chad produced approximately 469,000 tons of yams in 2023, ranking it as the 8th largest producer globally in this crop.
• Sugarcane production in Chad amounted to about 454,000 tons in 2023, supporting local sugar industries and consumption.
• Maize production was approximately 354,000 tons in 2023, serving as a key cereal crop for the country’s diet and economy.
• The country produced around 288,000 tons of cassava in 2023, a crucial root crop for both food and industrial uses.
• Rice production in Chad was approximately 224,000 tons in 2023, contributing to domestic food supply and market needs.
• Sweet potato production reached about 218,000 tons in 2023, adding to the diversity of root and tuber crops cultivated.
• Sesame seed production was approximately 210,000 tons in 2023, indicating its importance as an export crop and source of income.
• Beans were produced at a level of about 150,000 tons in 2023, serving as an important legume for nutrition and agriculture.
• Cotton production was quantified at 165,480 480-lb bales in 2023, reflecting its role as a major cash crop for Chad’s economy.
• Besides these major crops, Chad also produced smaller quantities of various other agricultural products, contributing to the country’s diverse agricultural sector.

• The table presents leading economic indicators for Chad from 1980 to 2024, illustrating trends in GDP, GDP per capita, GDP in nominal terms, real GDP growth, and government debt as a percentage of GDP.

• In 1980, Chad's GDP was valued at 2.3 billion US dollars (PPP), with a GDP per capita of 498 US dollars (PPP), and a nominal GDP of 1.0 billion US dollars, experiencing a significant negative real growth rate of -6.0%, with government debt data not available.

• By 1985, Chad's GDP increased to 3.6 billion US dollars (PPP), with GDP per capita rising to 704 US dollars (PPP), and nominal GDP reaching 1.3 billion US dollars, experiencing a positive real growth of 7.9%; government debt data remains unavailable.

• In 1990, GDP further grew to 5.2 billion US dollars (PPP), with GDP per capita at 872 US dollars (PPP), and nominal GDP at 2.5 billion US dollars, with a modest real growth rate of 3.2%; government debt data not provided.

• The 1995 data shows GDP at 6.8 billion US dollars (PPP), GDP per capita at 970 US dollars (PPP), and nominal GDP at 2.2 billion US dollars, with a slight negative real growth of -0.8%; government debt data remains unavailable.

• In 2000, Chad's GDP reached 8.4 billion US dollars (PPP), with GDP per capita at 1,005 US dollars (PPP), and nominal GDP at 2.1 billion US dollars, experiencing a negative real growth of -0.9%; government debt was 49.9% of GDP.

• The period from 2005 to 2008 shows rapid economic growth: in 2005, GDP was 18.9 billion US dollars (PPP), GDP per capita was 1,875 US dollars (PPP), and nominal GDP was 9.1 billion US dollars, with an 8.3% real growth and government debt at 20.9%; in 2006, GDP increased to 19.8 billion US dollars, with a slight real growth of 1.7%, government debt at 19.0%; in 2007, GDP reached 21.2 billion US dollars, with 3.9% real growth, debt at 16.0%; and in 2008, GDP was 22.5 billion US dollars, with 4.0% growth, debt at 14.6%.
• The 2009 data indicates GDP of 23.3 billion US dollars (PPP), with a 2.9% real growth rate, and government debt at 22.6%; nominal GDP was 13.0 billion US dollars.

• From 2010 to 2014, Chad experienced robust growth: in 2010, GDP was 26.0 billion US dollars (PPP), with a 10.5% growth rate and government debt at 22.5%; in 2011, GDP increased slightly to 26.9 billion US dollars, with 1.3% growth; in 2012, GDP reached 29.3 billion US dollars with 6.9% growth; in 2013, GDP was 31.4 billion US dollars with 5.6% growth; and in 2014, GDP was 34.0 billion US dollars, with a 6.1% growth rate and government debt at 29.4%.
• During 2015, GDP was 34.7 billion US dollars (PPP), with a slight growth of 1.4%, and government debt increased to 32.1%; nominal GDP was 14.5 billion US dollars.
• In 2016, GDP declined to 32.9 billion US dollars, with a negative growth of -6.3%, and government debt rose to 38.1%; GDP per capita decreased to 2,256 US dollars (PPP).
• The 2017 data shows a slight decrease in GDP to 32.8 billion US dollars, with a -2.0% growth rate, and government debt at 36.8%; GDP per capita was 2,182 US dollars (PPP).
• In 2018, GDP increased to 36.0 billion US dollars, with a 5.9% growth rate, and government debt at 33.3%; GDP per capita rose to 2,325 US dollars (PPP).
• The 2019 figures indicate GDP of 39.3 billion US dollars, with a 6.6% growth rate, and government debt at 38.0%; GDP per capita was 2,462 US dollars (PPP).
• In 2020, GDP slightly decreased to 36.8 billion US dollars, with a negative growth of -2.1%, and government debt increased to 41.2%; GDP per capita was 2,240 US dollars (PPP).
• The 2021 data shows GDP rebounding to 41.0 billion US dollars, with a marginal negative growth of -0.9%, and government debt at 42.4%; GDP per capita increased to 2,422 US dollars (PPP).
• In 2022, Chad's GDP grew to 45.5 billion US dollars, with a positive growth of 3.6%, and government debt decreased to 34.5%; GDP per capita reached 2,612 US dollars (PPP).
• The 2023 data reports GDP at 49.4 billion US dollars, with a 4.9% growth rate, and government debt at 32.7%; GDP per capita increased to 2,758 US dollars (PPP).
• For 2024, GDP is projected at 52.2 billion US dollars, with a 3.2% growth rate, and government debt at 31.5%; GDP per capita is expected to reach 2,832 US dollars (PPP).

openai_summarised_points: • The treemap of Chad's exports in 2019 is referenced but not detailed in the provided content.
• Chad's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) based on purchasing power parity was estimated at $28.62 billion in 2017.
• The real GDP growth rate in 2017 was -3.1%, indicating economic contraction during that year.
• GDP per capita in 2017 was approximately $2,300, reflecting the average economic output per person.
• Gross national saving as a percentage of GDP was 15.5% in 2017, indicating the proportion of income saved rather than consumed.
• The sectoral composition of GDP in 2017 was: agriculture at 52.3%, industry at 14.7%, and services at 33.1%.
• As of 2011, approximately 46.7% of Chad's population was living below the poverty line.
• The Gini index for income distribution in 2011 was 43.3, suggesting a moderate level of income inequality.
• Consumer price inflation in 2017 was recorded at -0.9%, indicating deflation.
• Chad's labor force in 2017 comprised approximately 5.654 million individuals.
• In 2006, employment by occupation was estimated at 80% in agriculture and 20% in industry and services.
• The government’s revenue in 2017 was approximately $1.337 billion, while expenditures totaled about $1.481 billion.
• The budget deficit in 2017 was -1.5% of GDP, indicating a shortfall between revenues and expenditures.
• Public debt in 2017 was 52.5% of GDP, reflecting the country's debt level relative to its economic output.
• Key industries in Chad include oil, cotton textiles, brewing, natron (sodium carbonate), soap, cigarettes, and construction materials.
• Industrial production experienced a decline of 4% in 2017.
• Electrification coverage was minimal: total population at 4%, urban areas at 14%, and rural areas at 1% in 2013.
• Electricity production in 2016 was approximately 224.3 million kWh.
• Electricity generation sources in 2017 were predominantly fossil fuels (~98%), with renewable sources (~3%) and no hydro or nuclear energy.
• Electricity consumption in 2016 was about 208.6 million kWh; exports and imports of electricity were zero in 2016.
• Chad's agricultural products include cotton, sorghum, millet, peanuts, sesame, corn, rice, potatoes, onions, cassava (manioc, tapioca), and livestock such as cattle, sheep, goats, and camels.
• Total exports in 2017 were valued at $2.464 billion.
• Main export commodities include oil, livestock, cotton, sesame, gum arabic, and shea butter.
• Export partner countries in 2017 were the US (38.7%), China (16.6%), Netherlands (15.7%), UAE (12.2%), and India (6.3%).
• Total imports in 2017 amounted to $2.16 billion.
• Major import commodities are machinery and transportation equipment, industrial goods, foodstuffs, and textiles.
• Import partner countries in 2017 included China (19.9%), Cameroon (17.2%), France (17%), US (5.4%), India (4.9%), and Senegal (4.5%).
• External debt as of 31 December 2017 was approximately $1.724 billion.
• Reserves of foreign exchange and gold stood at $22.9 million as of 31 December 2017.
